texts.definition: The event of avatars, units, or other game elements entering game worlds.
markups: <style="Definition">The event of avatars, units, or other game elements entering game worlds.</style>

All games where new game elements appear in game worlds during gameplay must provide means by which these game elements are introduced. <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> is one of the common ways of doing this and simply places game elements in the game environment; letting them be able to do actions in the game world and letting them be affected by actions in the game world.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Backgammon">Backgammon</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pachisi">Pachisi</link></style> are early examples of games that make use of <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style>. In both these games, players can insert game elements into their respective "game world" as actions.

Many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> have spawning due to their themes making the existence of teleportation, illusions, or the summoning of beings from death realms or other dimensions a possibility.

The arcade game Gauntlet let players enter ongoing games by being spawned into locations near the other players. It also has game objects that spawn monsters which players can destroy. Minecraft also has such objects, called Monster Spawners, but monsters may actually spawn in from any opaque blocks in full or partial darkness. Dying in Minecraft also results in Spawning, but at the same location every time one dies. Players of Torchlight have three options when their characters die: Spawning at the point of death but with a loss of money and experience points, Spawning at the start of the level and only losing money, or Spawning at the town without losing anything.

Many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> make use of <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style>, either to provide <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> to players or to let players reenter the game after being killed by other players. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style> move the places where players can spawn as battle fronts move while the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unreal%20Tournament%20series">Unreal Tournament series</link></style> have more random <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style>; this is also the case for the "special" infected in multiplayer games in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> of game elements controlled by players, most often <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, are either used to effect the initial set up of a game environment, to let them enter new <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, or to revive their game elements as part of <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> (the use of <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="life-penalties">Life Penalties</link></style> practically requires <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> to be present in a game). <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> can also be used to introduce <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> during gameplay, including reintroducing <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> after they have been destroyed. In games where <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> spawn, <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style> can modify how often this occurs and what <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> spawn. A general choice regarding <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> which is independent of these reasons are if the <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> can occur anywhere or if it is restricted to specific <style="Link"><link="spawn-points">Spawn Points</link></style>. A special location in relation to this exists when the <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> is tied to <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style>: players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> may respawn at their point of death. While this somewhat reduced how noticeable the pattern is, it may provides continuation but at the expense of potentially causing immediate problems again since the death causes may still be present. Even if <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> are not respawned where they died, this location can still be interesting to return to if <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> has been dropped there as a consequence of the deaths (see <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> for an example of this).

Besides where <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> occurs the design of <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> is most often a question of <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>. One issue related to this is that players typically are disadvantaged when <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style>. This may be from other <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> due to the same <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> that caused the <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> or due to players simply lacking a proper <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> directly after <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style>. Several design options exist that can help <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> players through providing <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style>: letting them have <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style> as <style="Link"><link="temporary-abilities">Temporary Abilities</link></style>, making <style="Link"><link="camping">Camping</link></style> around <style="Link"><link="spawn-points">Spawn Points</link></style> impossible (for example through <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style>), or letting them purchase or otherwise receive <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> to ensure a certain level of preparedness. Letting players have several <style="Link"><link="spawn-points">Spawn Points</link></style> to choose from is another possibility, and gives players a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to make <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> of where to spawn as well as take into consideration nearby <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style>. The design choices may of course also be appropriate for other types of <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> besides that of <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>.

While <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> can be experienced as part of other <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> combined with <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style>, the actual <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> action can force players to have <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>. This is not only a <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style> (especially when combined with <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style>) since it can let or force players to observe their new environments before beginning to take actions.

When <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> should occur is self-evident when it is used to re-introduce "killed" game elements but in other cases this may be an important design decision. This since it can regulate how common or scarce <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style> are, how easy it is to reach <style="Link"><link="grind-achievements">Grind Achievements</link></style>, or how <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> a game provides. In <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> this may be done only when players are active (to balance the <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> actions to player actions) or be use to make the games at least partly into a form of <style="Link"><link="tick-based-games">Tick-Based Games</link></style>.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>

Except for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternative%20Realities">Alternative Realities</link></style> which have teleportation as a feature, <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> is rarely easy to explain within a <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. A weak solution is arrivals from <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> but this may instead raise the question why one cannot enter the Inaccessible Areas if one can leave them
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>

When players have the opportunity to choose where to spawn, this typically requires them to select the <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> point on a <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screen</link></style> (typically a map). Examples of this can be found in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style>.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> can be used to move the focus of gameplay so that it advances <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. This is mainly done after major <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style> such as completing important goals or <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> have led to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cut%20Scenes">Cut Scenes</link></style> and players after this need to be positioned in new places in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. Another example of how <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> can focus players' attention as part of telling a story is the appearance of new <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> - due to the nature of <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> this is typically in the form of summoning some unearthly creature.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> can most often be seen as <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> by abstract <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Producers">Producers</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, and is often done at specific <style="Link"><link="spawn-points">Spawn Points</link></style>. It gives game designs a way of avoiding <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> (as well as <style="Link"><link="early-elimination">Early Elimination</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="team-elimination">Team Elimination</link></style>) while having still having <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, and also allowing an easy solution to introduce <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style>. The latter can provide a basic functionality for <style="Link"><link="interruptibility">Interruptibility</link></style> since it makes it easier to re-introduce players after being away from gameplay. <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> are often associated with <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> from the players' perspective when they occur as part of <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style> since players can first notice the <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> and the lost gameplay opportunities when they have spawned.

Since <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> introduces some type of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style>, it is difficult to combine with <style="Link"><link="steadily-decreasing-resources">Steadily Decreasing Resources</link></style>. An exception is when the actual <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> uses up a <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style>, as for example how "ticks" are used in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style> when players spawn.

As long as <style="CurrentLink">Spawning</style> of <style="Link"><link="teams">Team</link></style> members occur in games with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="team-elimination">Team Elimination</link></style> is impossible.
